div.p:
It was only on my return from Staffordshire yesterday that I
received your kind note of the 7th. I saw you at the meeting of the
R.G.S. and intended then to acknowledge the kindness which prompted
you to think of me in connection with your remaining volumes. But you escaped my sight in the crowd. I shall always be heard of at
Murrays56 Abermarle St. and beg to assure you that I shall peruse your works with double interest from the circumstance
of having known you and participated so lagelylargely in your generosity.
I am keeping the other three to be a treat where far away from the
hastlehassle of civilisation. My countrymen give me little leizure now,
just as I suppose yours to do when in Germany. I however cannot get
away into quiet by going over there as you do by coming over here.
I hope that you found your family well. As for me, my poor father
died when I was near SeteTete on my way to the East coast and there is
no one to whom I should have been more pleased to relate my ad-
ventures than to him. My poor mother is ill through the excitement
of parting with three sons from distant parts of the world on one
day.

TereThere is some prospect of my getting back to my adopted land in
January, but I go first to PotugalPortugal. Wherever you may be placed I sh
shall always read every word I see about you with pleasing interest.
And I pray that our Heavenly Father may protect you and that through
the merits of our blessed RedumerRedeemer you & I may meet in joy after
all our wanderings all over.

My work which you receive so kindly is a poor little thing as
compared to yours. You have at least five times as much perseverance
in handling the pen that I have.
